children.value: Generating a General Access REST API Key
For more information about authenticating using an API key, please consult the
For more information on the differences between the APIs, check out our article on the differences between our
that will help you identify the key later on. If you would like it to be read-only, check the
A unique API key will be generated. Copy it to a safe place and click
Once you click Close you will be asked to confirm that you copied the API key.
This is your last chance to copy the key
— you will only be able to see the last 4 characters of the key in the PagerDuty interface after you confirm. If you lose a key you will need to delete it and create a new one.
Once created, you will see your key appear in the list of keys on the API Access page, with versioning noted.
One can access and download the
JSON specification for the PagerDuty REST API at the following URL:
Integrations that Require REST API Access
The following integrations require the generation of a REST API key for setup:
Generating a Personal REST API key
enabled, users can create personal REST API keys on the
tab of their user profile. Requests made using personal REST API keys will be restricted to the user's permissions.
Getting Started with the REST API
The best place to start your API journey is with our
for suggestions and examples of what other customers have done.
When you're ready for more, head over to the
site for detailed documentation on our API endpoints.
for examples of scripts that interact with our API. Scripts are available in Ruby, Python and PHP; most are simple
calls with variables defined at the top where you will substitute your own values. These scripts should be easy to run from the command line on Unix, Linux and Mac.
endpoint of our REST API from the command line as an example. In these examples, you will need to replace
with a valid v2 REST API key. If you do not already have an access token, please take a look at our article on
With an API key, I can run the following command to list the details for all of my account's schedules:
I would then see the following output in my command line interface in JSON format:

{
  "type": "info",
  "title": "Note",
  "body": "This output has been formatted for readability. Your output may appear

until you have used a program to format the JSON for readability."
}

Reading the documentation again, I see that I can also pass two parameters of interest to
. I can include these parameters in the request as follows:
Please note that submitted data should be
. This means that here and elsewhere, the first argument can be submitted at the end of the URL with a question mark (
), and every other argument after the first using an ampersand (
). You should not include quotation marks around arguments, even if the argument has a space within it (i.e. for a service named
). Instead, using percent encoding, spaces would be represented as

flag that can be used to automatically encode your parameters properly. We suggest using this flag in most situations to avoid potential issues with special characters in your parameters. I can run the same command as above with the
